lines: You have seen your friend Marsha and her husband John socially for a long time. They have a very peculiar relationship. John insists on controlling every aspect of Marsha's life.

One day when you are talking to Marsha, she confesses that about three years ago, she began seeing another man -- one who is kind, gentle and loving. She has been thinking about leaving John for this other man but is unsure if she can.

This must have been a difficult decision. Giving her advice might mean taking responsibility for a decision that she, alone, should make. Stepping aside might distance you from your friend for a while, but in the end, it is worth it.
Advice given under duress is almost always bad advice. Marsha resents you for meddling, regardless of the outcome.
What kind of advice are you going to give her?
#DIVORCE JOHN AND MARRY THE OTHER MAN

Marsha tells you that she and John have already been to several marriage counselors. Two marriage counselors got so fed up with John that, for the sake of their OWN sanity, they refused to see the couple anymore. Two others said that the
problem was Marsha's own lack of assertiveness and her desire to be controlled, which Marsha knew anyway but couldn't help. Do you want to give Marsha any more advice?
Good, you've meddled enough as it is!
What advice will you be giving now, Sigmund?
#DIVORCE JOHN AND MARRY THE OTHER MAN

You WOULD recommend something like this. Taking the cowardly, untrustworthy way has long been your trademark in life. Marsha feels uncomfortable doing this and later resents you for making the suggestion.
Obviously this piece of advice really isn't very good. If Marsha could comfortably continue the affair, she wouldn't be asking for your advice, now, would she?

Very simple advice. Just like that, pick up a whole relationship, a whole life, and transfer to another. Think about what phase of life you are in now. Chances are John and Marsha have been together for twenty years or more. For a woman
who is used to getting structure and direction from a person like John, this kind of move would be terrifying.

Your intentions are good -- you want to see Marsha happier than she is now. Regardless of how a relationship looks to outsiders, when two people stay together, they satisfy SOME kind of need for each other. Believe it or not, she may
actually DESIRE a man who is as domineering as John.
Your advice to her is logical, but people often do not act that way. As a result, Marsha's ambivalence turns to anger, which she directs at you for butting into her life.
What kind of advice is this? I can't imagine why you would even suggest it, and neither can Marsha. She resents you for butting into her life, and the two of you begin to grow apart.
The sound of breaking glass punctuates your otherwise relaxing afternoon (Marsha is throwing a bit of a fit. You are used to this.) You are glad you don't have to deal with any of this.
